text: testified as follows:
- - - EXAMINATION

Good afternoon, Janet.  My name is Joseph Blum and I represent Mercedes-Benz in the cases that have been brought from the fire here at Clemens Cleaning Village. I'm going to ask you series of questions today.  If at any time you don't understand my question, please let me know and I'll be happy to restate the question.  And I ask you also to keep all your responses verbal because the court reporter has to take down everything we're saying, and she can't take down nods of your head or shrugs of your shoulders.  Okay?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: I understand.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: I would also ask you try to wait until I finish asking my question before you start to speak, because although in a normal conversation you would do that, here it's a little more difficult because the court reporter has to take everything down.  Okay?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: Uh-huh.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Also, if at any time you want to take a break, please let me know. And is there anything that would prevent you from testifying clearly and accurately today?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: No.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  By whom are you employed?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: Clemens Uniform.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And what do you do there?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: Office manager, accounting.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  And how long have you worked -- is it Clemens Cleaning Village that is your employer?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: Yes, Clemens Cleaning Village, Inc., yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And how long have you worked for Clemens Cleaning Village?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: July of 1983.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And did you come here right out of school, to Clemens Cleaning Village?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: No.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  Tell us what your educational background is?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: I went to, I graduated from college, Eastern Mennonite College, in 1976.  And then I took accounting classes at Temple in -- that would have been like '78 and '79.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And when you got your degree, what was it in?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: Math.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: All right.  When you went to Temple, did you get any kind of certificate or additional degree?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: No.  I just took accounting classes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And when you were at Temple, were you going there full time?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: No; part time.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And were you working at that time?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: I was working at American Olean Tile.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And what did you do there?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: I was in inventory control.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And how long did you work there in that capacity?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: Two years, '77 to '79.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And after that where did you go to work?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: I worked at Tuthill Pump Company out in Chicago, Illinois.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And what did you do there?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: I was in accounting.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And how long did you stay there at the pump company?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: That was from '79 to '83.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  And then did you come back here to work?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: Yeah, then we moved back here, yeah.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And are you a member of the Clemens family?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  Randy is your brother?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: When you first came to work here at Clemens, what facility or physically where did you work?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: When I actually started working in 1983, I did all of the accounting work out of my home.  I had an office set up in my home and I did it out of there.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  And was the company at that point operating dry cleaning --
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: -- as well as --
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: Just dry cleaning at that point. I'm sorry.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: When did the company start to perform what I'll call the uniform services?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: As best as I can remember, it would have been 1986.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: When that first started, did it start out of one of the dry cleaning locations?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: Yes, it did.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Which one did it start out of?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: 614 East Main Street in Lansdale.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: At its height how many locations did the company have in terms of dry cleaning?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: We had three dry cleaning plants and two drop stores.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And at some point did the company sell off all the dry cleaning operations?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: Yes, we did.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And when was that?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: It was in bits and pieces, but we got out of dry cleaning completely in 2009.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And when did the company first start operations at the facility on 5th Street?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: As close as I can recall, I think it would be 1989.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And when you first moved on to 5th Street, the company only occupied like one section of the building; is that correct?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: That is correct.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And at what point did it expand beyond that first section?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: I don't really know.  I honestly don't know all the dates of when that was.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: All right.  And was there work that was done in the building as you expanded it, your operations?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: What kind of work do you recall doing inside the building?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: Are you talking about me personally or --
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: No.  The company.
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: All right.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: I didn't think, you don't look like somebody out there swinging a hammer.
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: That's why this was --
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: I apologize for not being clear. What type of work did the company do in the building?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: Well, I mean, we started with like one washer and then just kept, so it was always washers, dryers, and then the tablecloth press was added to press tablecloths.  But that was fairly early on because that was in the first section.  I'm just trying to recall how the sections were. So tablecloth press, washers, dryers.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And when you made those changes, did you alter the building in any way?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: So when we went from one section to two sections, they just cut an opening in the drywall to make a doorway through.  They made a doorway through at the washers and dryers and then up, up near the office where there was an aisleway.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Any other changes that you remember being made to the physical structure at that point?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: No.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: At some point you expanded beyond the first three units even further.  Do you remember whether or not there were any physical changes that were made at that point?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: To the building?
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Yes.
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: Well, after we went from three, from the first three to the next one, then there was a block wall there.  So then they had, you know, cut an opening for a block wall and make a ramp down because it was two different levels.  So we had to have a ramp between the two levels.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: All right.
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: And we just used that next section that we had that was strictly for warehouse.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And the other interior walls between those units, were they all cinderblock or were they just drywall?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: The way the building was constructed was that there were three units, and then the cinderblock wall, so the first three units only had a double -- it was like a double drywall, fireproof drywall, whatever.  But that was, it was like two layers of drywall.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: It didn't have a block wall.  So the first three units and then there was a cinderblock.  That's what the fire code was at the time the building was constructed.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And at any time during any of that construction, was there ever discussion about installing any type of sprinkler systems?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: My brother handled more of that, but it was my understanding that the North Penn Water Authority, when we looked into it, did not have sufficient water pressure for us to have sprinkler systems in our building.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And was there ever a discussion about putting in a fire alarm during any of that construction?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: I don't recall any.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Was there ever a discussion about putting in any kind of smoke detectors?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: I don't recall any.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Do you remember a point in time when the company installed a video security system?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: Uh-huh, I do remember that.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: When approximately did that take place?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: As best as I can recall, it would have been 2015.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And why was that done in 2015?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: There was two issues.  One was some stealing and missing items that were happening.  And the other issue was at the time clock where people were punching, like they would come in and punch in at 6 o'clock and they would punch someone else at 6 o'clock that wasn't in yet.  So there was an issue with the time clock, so I know that's why we had wanted the time clock.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  And who did the work to install that video system?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: I honestly don't recall.  I'm sorry, I don't remember.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Do you remember where the video cameras were?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: Well, I know we had one in the office, and I know that we had one at the time clock.  And then I believe that there was one at the loading dock, as I recall.  I think there was only four, four cameras?  That's all I recall, I'm sorry.  I don't remember.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: That's okay.  Was there ever any discussions before the fire about the company upgrading the interior of the building or upgrading the equipment that you were using?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: Well, we were in the process of making plans that the people that were in the second end building were going to move to the end unit, and we were going to be taking over another, the other section.  So we were going to move them over.  But that was just in the planning stages, nothing was started with that yet.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And what was it you were then planning to do after the tenant moved over, what was Clemens, what were the Clemens people going to do, what was going to change?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: So what was going to change was, we wanted the more automated sorting system, and that took up a lot of floor space, and so that was -- that was the reason that we wanted to, because where we sort was just like this little area, so we needed more space to be able to sort the garments with this new automated system.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And what would the advantage have been for you of the automated system?  Not for you, but for the company?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: More accurate sorting.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Would it have occurred faster, the sorting?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: Yeah, I mean, that's what was it supposed to be, faster, more efficient, yeah.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: How far had you gotten in the process of planning for that?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: So we started putting the microchips in the garments, because they had told us that that took a long time till you get like all the chips in.  So we had started putting the chips in the garments.  And we had bought the computers that were needed for the sorting and the scanning.  And we had the portal that read that, we had that, and that had arrived and that was in the back building for lack of space, so then that wasn't destroyed in the fire.  And so we had purchased, I guess we had purchased all of the equipment, but we had not actually set any of it up yet before the fire occurred.  But we had purchased everything that we needed to set that up.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And did that include like what I'll call the physical rack system, whatever, for the sorting system that you had?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: No.  That was going to have to be installed yet.  That was not installed.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And did you have estimates at that time about how much it was going to cost to install all that?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: Randy took care of that, so he would have had that.  I didn't have that information.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  But you had gotten that far that you had talked about what the estimates were to put that in?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: He would have that, yeah.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And were you on the property the day before the fire?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And do you remember anything unusual occurring that day?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: Not at all.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  What time did you leave the facility that day?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: Probably around 5 o'clock.  That's usually when I leave.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And where did you sit in the facility?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: So my office was in unit, like we called it Unit 3, in the front.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: So that would have been in the original section that was leased by the company?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: I don't know what you call the original section.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: You know, I'm going to stop for a minute.  If you can look at Exhibit No. 4, okay, can you tell me with the red numbers which unit you were in?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: It would be 4 on here.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And was the base unit for the video system in that office?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: No.  It was in 5.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Who else worked with you in the office, in the physical office you worked in?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: John Camioni, he's no longer with us, and Andrew Bourlet, he's no longer with us.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  And what did they do?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: So Andrew was customer service and John was accounts receivable.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: So if we walked out of the office door for your office and you looked out into the plant, what would have been in front of you?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: That would have been where they did the sorting, the garment sorting.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Did they do that on a table?  What did the sorting area look like?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: Oh, okay.  So I meant the garments, so like the garments that came out of the steam tunnel, they came down like a conveyor rack and then they took them and they had like a conveyor system that they sort them on.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And after they sort them, where did they go?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: They had a rail for each driver, so after they had them all like assembled, then they would go on the rails for the drivers. So that would have been like what they put here.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Where all those lines are?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: Uh-huh.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And those rails for the drivers, like how high up did they go?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: So they -- you could reach them. They were double-deckered, but you could reach up to the top one.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And how long were those rails, if you were standing at the front of it, how deep into the building would it go?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: I would say 20 to 22 feet, maybe.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And then what was beyond these sorted clothes racks, what was beyond those as you went further back in the building?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: That's where the drivers, this all was open in here where the drivers would pull to load their trucks.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And were there clean mats also stored in that area?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: Right, there would be -- there was a mat rack in that same section there, right about where this is marked.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: All right.
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: Clean mats, yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And if you walked out of your office to the right, there was a wall there, is that correct, between Unit 4 and Unit 5 that's marked on that diagram?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: Yes, uh-huh.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: How big was the opening between Unit 4 and 5, the walls?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: Oh, no.  4 and 5, between 4 and 5, there wasn't a wall there.  The wall was between 5 and 6.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  So the wall between 4 and 5 had been removed?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: Completely out.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And then so if you went to the right coming out of your office in 4, what was there on the floor in Unit 5?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: I have to think back.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Take your time.
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: The steam tunnel was definitely here, and then there was a table that someone worked at.  And she like sorted the, that's what we call the executive wear, the shirts, dress pants and dress shirts.  So there was a table there that she used at the top here. And then there was a table there that was used for measuring inventory.  And sometimes they would use that for folding things, too, but there was a table there.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And was there pressing units there?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: So the pressing units would have been like down in this area.  There was a pants press -- oh, the shirt press was out here.  So the shirt press was -- this is a while ago -- the shirt press, like the table was here and the shirt press was here, and then the pants press was down here.  So this was pressing equipment here.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And was that electrically operated pressing equipment?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: So it had -- it needed air to operate, like the air compressor.  And then it was hooked up to a steam boiler.  So it was like steam, not really electrical.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Where was the steam boiler --
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: So the steam boiler, we had the boiler room is back in the back here, I guess this is --
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: The back --
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: I'm trying to think of which unit the steam boiler was in.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Was it in the addition that had been added or was it in the original building?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: It was in the original building.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  And was it in Unit 4, 5, or 6, if you know?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: That's what I'm looking at.  It was in 6.  It was in 6.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And just so we're clear, though, the pressing stations that we just described, they were along what would have been the wall between 4 and 5, they were in that spot?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  And did the employees in that spot, did they have like electrical fans or anything that they operated there to help keep themselves cool?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: There was a big ceiling fan that would have been like right over there.  But every station, you know, like had fans.  So I'm sure they would have had fans because no matter where you worked in there, there were fans.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  Do you recall, were there ever any times when electrical work, where Clemens itself hired people to do electrical work in those units, 4, 5, or 6?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: I mean, we would have always used Bergey's Electric when we did any electrical work.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Do you remember there being any problems with the electrical work?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: No.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Was there a company that maintained the garage doors for you?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: KJ Doors.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: How often were they out there to look at the doors?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: They would definitely come once a year to do maintenance.  If I recall, it was usually like going into the wintertime when they would come and check the doors out, because we had issues sometimes where the doors would go up and not come down or something.  So they usually came towards the wintertime.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: What, if anything, did you review to prepare for your deposition today?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: As far as?
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Well, did you review any documents before you came here today to prepare?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: I'm not sure what you mean.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Well, you knew you were coming here today; correct?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Did you look at anything to refresh your recollection before you came?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: I had, the only thing I looked at last week was the information that I had given concerning the invoices for the subcontractors after the insurance stopped paying.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  Right in front of you here, I'm going to ask you to take a look at Exhibit No. 2 there, if you just grab that right there.  If you look, that's a Notice of Deposition, if you look at what's titled Page 3, it has a list of topics on there. Have you seen that list of topics before?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  And did you and Randy discuss which of these topics would best be covered by each of you?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: No.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Before you came here today, did you understand that you would be the witness who would testify on behalf of Clemens Cleaning Village about the day-to-day business operations?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And what about the day-to-day business operations for the P.R. Family Partnership?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: I am not, nothing to do with the P.R. Family Partnership.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  In your capacity of working do you ever do any work for that?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: No.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: In terms of the second bullet point, which is the property damage claims as alleged in the Complaint, and I'm going to be more specific, in terms of the equipment and inventory that was lost, are you the best person to give that testimony?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: It depends I guess what you're asking.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  In terms of the losses that the company sustained that were not covered by insurance, would you be the best person to know those numbers?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: Well, I mean, I went down the list with the adjuster, if that's what you're asking, as far as the property loss.  Is that what you're asking or --
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Well, I am going to ask about that and I'm concerned about that.  But what I really want to know the answer to is what is Clemens Cleaning Village claiming that it was not paid for?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: Okay.  I assembled that documentation.  Is that what you're asking?
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  So therefore you're the best person from the company to tell us what those claims are.  Is that true?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: Okay.  Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: It is, okay.  And how about the business interruption claims, were you familiar with the business interruption claims that were put together?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: I did that, yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And are you the best person to tell us what portions of the business interruption claims were not paid by the insurance?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  You can put that aside now, thank you. All right.  You made a reference to a document that you had put together.  Could you look, there's a whole stack of exhibits there, look for Exhibit No. 9. Is that the document that you put together, Exhibit 9?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: All right.  And you were the person who assembled all this?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  What was the purpose of putting this together?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: To document what costs we had for the subcontracting of the uniforms after the insurance stopped paying the business interruption.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: All right.  So can you tell me what pages 3215 through 3217, what do those pages represent?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: That is the way the, our executive wear, we had to send out to a dry cleaner because the shirts and pants are pressed.  And so that was the executive wear, and that's the way the dry cleaner gave us, that's the bill he gave us like that.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And would the period, say 8/7, it doesn't have a year?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: That would have been -- he didn't write a year on, but that would have been 2017.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  And is it accurate that by the time you got to 8/25 of '17, that would have been the last time he invoiced you for those services?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: Actually, I'm pretty sure that we continued using his services in September, but we did not claim that because we were operating everything in this building, but we just didn't get the shirt equipment going. And so we didn't include that in this claim.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: All right.  So is it accurate then that in terms of time the last claim is for 8/25?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: That's correct.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: All right.  Can you take a look at page 3218 for me.  What does page 3218 represent?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: This was, we always had a dry cleaner machine -- before we had the fire, we had a dry cleaning machine.  So then certain things that came in that were real greasy and oily, we would dry clean in our machine.  And this K Cleaners did that work for us because we didn't have a dry cleaning machine anymore.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: So is it accurate that what page 3218 and 3219 represent are the portions of that expense for K Cleaners -- I'm sorry, just page 3218 is for K Cleaners for the period when the insurance company did not reimburse you?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And are the dates that appear on the left-hand side, are they invoice dates?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: Yes, they are.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And so is it accurate that the last invoice that you're making a claim for from K Cleaners is 8/31/17?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: That's correct.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  And if you look at page 3219, this one is for Town Valet Cleaners; is that right?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: Okay, so that's what this is, this Town Valet, this was his invoices.  And I think that this whole packet doesn't include, we had like copies of all of the invoices, and then this was missing, and so then that's why that was included in here.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  So you used the words "this" and "that" quite a few in there.
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: I'm sorry.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: That's okay, because then on the record it's not clear. So what you're talking about is the handwritten pages at the beginning of Exhibit 9 end up being totaled on your QuickBooks report on page 3219?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: That is correct.

And then there was also a time period that they would not pay the rental, it was -- and I'm sorry, I don't remember that right now, how many days it was, it escapes me.  There was a certain period that it covered, so this was what we paid to lease the trucks that we needed until we could buy new trucks. And then I put what the insurance covered on that, so the total on the truck rental on the back, on 3228, that total came from the other page, $40,862.84, and then received from insurance, that's the amount that we received from the insurance.  So then that was the amount that was unreimbursed for the truck lease.

So our normal Wednesday sales at that point would have been 15,000, and we didn't have any sales that Wednesday.

text: We do.  Not to the extent.  We used to use them for all of the shop rags.  Now we just do the print shop rags, yes, print shop rags for them.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: So you're saying that you used them for all of the shop rags after the fire, up until --
speaker: MR. DIVIS

text: Up until -- we use them for all. Now we process the red and the blue ones inhouse.  We just send the green ones out.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And as I understand your testimony, you had never used Kleentech before the fire at issue; is that accurate?
speaker: MR. DIVIS

text: That's correct.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: MacIntosh Linen, what are they? What did they do?
speaker: MR. DIVIS

text: They're a big commercial laundry in Allentown.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Had you ever used that contractor before the fire at issue?
speaker: MR. DIVIS

text: No, never.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And do you still use MacIntosh Linen?
speaker: MR. DIVIS

text: No, not at all.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: What about Gemini Linen, can you tell me what business they're in?
speaker: MR. DIVIS

text: They do table linens, napkins and tablecloths.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And had you ever used Gemini Linen before the fire at issue?
speaker: MR. DIVIS

text: No, not at all.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Did you still use Gemini today?
speaker: MR. DIVIS

text: No.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Acme Uniform, had you ever used them before the fire?
speaker: MR. DIVIS

text: No.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And do you still use them on occasion --
speaker: MR. DIVIS

text: No, never.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: -- presently? Presently does Clemens, do you own all of the vehicles in your fleet?
speaker: MR. DIVIS

text: At this time we do, yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: In June of 2016 how many leased vehicles did Clemens Cleaning have?
speaker: MR. DIVIS

text: I believe it was three.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And were they all leased from Bergey's or --
speaker: MR. DIVIS

text: Yes, they were.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Were they all Sprinters?
speaker: MR. DIVIS

text: I don't want to say.  I'm not sure.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: How many vehicles did Clemens own back in June of 2016, vans, I'm talking about?
speaker: MR. DIVIS

text: I don't have that specific number here.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Do you know what type of vans they were?
speaker: MR. DIVIS

text: Well, we had some box trucks.  I know we had some Dodge Sprinters, we had some of the Ram trucks.  We had the Isuzu uniform trucks.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And did the vehicles, did they all have Clemens wrapping on them back in June of 2016?
speaker: MR. DIVIS

text: They did.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And the fleet that you have now, in terms of the vans that you use, who is the manufacturer of those vehicles?
speaker: MR. DIVIS

text: That we have now?
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Yes.
speaker: MR. DIVIS

text: I know we have three or four of the Ford Transits that we got since the fire.  We still have Isuzu box trucks.  And we have ProMasters.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Any other vehicles that are in your fleet now other than the ones you mentioned to me?
speaker: MR. DIVIS

text: I guess we still have some Dodge Sprinters.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: How many Dodge Sprinters are in your fleet now?
speaker: MR. DIVIS

text: I don't have that list in front of me.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: More than one?
speaker: MR. DIVIS

text: I honestly don't know.  I'm not a truck person.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Understood.  You mentioned Mr. Camioni?
speaker: MR. DIVIS

text: Camioni.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: He worked in the same office as you?
speaker: MR. DIVIS

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And he was in accounts receivable?
speaker: MR. DIVIS

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Does he still work for the company?
speaker: MR. DIVIS

text: No.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Do you know where he works now?
speaker: MR. DIVIS

text: He works, I don't know the name of the company, all I know is that it's an accounting firm.  He went to an accounting firm.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Mr. Camioni?
speaker: MR. DIVIS

text: Camioni.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: How old is he?
speaker: MR. DIVIS

text: About 33 or 4, maybe.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And he left the company when?
speaker: MR. DIVIS

text: He left the company late August of 2017.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And what were the circumstances under which he left the company?
speaker: MR. DIVIS

text: He just wanted -- he had an accounting background and he was going to go to an accounting firm to work to be a CPA.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  And then for your, for lack of a better, would you be in charge of the accounting department here?
speaker: MR. DIVIS

text: Yes, I would.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: How many people work in your department presently?
speaker: MR. DIVIS

text: For as far as accounting or the whole office?
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Accounting.
speaker: MR. DIVIS

text: Accounting is just myself and Brad Imel, I-M-E-L.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And then how many folks work in this plant in the office only as opposed to the workers down on the floor?
speaker: MR. DIVIS

text: Do you want me to count my brother?
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Sure.
speaker: MR. DIVIS

text: We have four office people, full-time office.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Are there people who work part time in the office?
speaker: MR. DIVIS

text: We have one guy that does other jobs plus the office.  He works full time, it's just that he's not full time in the office.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And then in terms of managing the folks on the floor, is that something that your brother is generally responsible for?
speaker: MR. DIVIS

text: We have a plant manager.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Who is that?
speaker: MR. DIVIS

text: Christina Kolb.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: K-O-L-B?
speaker: MR. DIVIS

text: Uh-huh.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Yes?
speaker: MR. DIVIS

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: How long has Christina been the plant manager?
speaker: MR. DIVIS

text: She started right when we came up, when we got back into the building here, so that would have been like August of 2017.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And who was the plant manager before Christina?
speaker: MR. DIVIS

text: The plant manager like when we were in the older building before the fire?
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: No; here, say in June of 2016, who was the plant manager, at the time of the fire at issue who was the plant manager?
speaker: MR. DIVIS

text: I think at that point, I think Scott Young was the plant manager at that point.  My brother did oversee a lot of the day-to-day plant operation at that point, but I believe Scott was like a charge person at that point.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And does Scott work for the company anymore?
speaker: MR. DIVIS

text: No, he doesn't.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Do you know where he works now?
speaker: MR. DIVIS

text: I do not.  I think he works for his dad.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: What business is that, if you know?
speaker: MR. DIVIS

text: Electrician.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Just in terms of the, Mr. Blum went through this with you, but the replacement cost of the -- excuse me, the towels, mops, uniform replacement, first aid, mats, linens, garment chips, emblems that you replaced, I suppose you had the figures -- correct me if I'm wrong -- in terms of what you had as an inventory for all of those items before the fire started?
speaker: MR. DIVIS

text: Which page are you on?
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Sure.  Page 3227.
speaker: MR. DIVIS

text: Okay.  I just want to make sure I was looking at the same thing.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: In other words, there's a cost there associated with the towels and mops that were lost in the fire; correct?
speaker: MR. DIVIS

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And in terms of the number of towels and mops, in terms of that inventory, were you the one that would have had that in the accounting department before the fire?
speaker: MR. DIVIS

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Same thing for the uniform replacement, first aid, mats, linens, garment chips, emblems, all of that was information that you would have had in the accounting office in terms of what you had or what you, meaning Clemens, had on hand before the fire; correct?
speaker: MR. DIVIS

text: Correct.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And the accountants that you use are who, what's the name of the firm?
speaker: MR. DIVIS

text: Baum Smith & Clemens.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Are they any relation to you?
speaker: MR. DIVIS

text: Tim Clemens, it's like a very, very distant relation.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Ma'am, that's all the questions I have for you.
speaker: MR. DIVIS

text: I do have one followup question.
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: - - - FURTHER EXAMINATION
You mentioned shop rags, there was red, blue, and green rags.  What was the distinction in terms of those?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: So the red rags are used by automobile mechanics and that. And then the blue rags are used by machine shops.  And they get metal shavings in that, so we always have to keep them separate when you wash them and everything like that. And then the green rags are printing company rags.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And why are they kept separated?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: Because of the solvents that are in the printing rags.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  And do you know what those solvents are?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: I don't.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  That's it.
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: I don't have any questions.
speaker: MR. ACKLEN

text: No.
speaker: MR. REICH

text: (Witness excused.)
(Whereupon the deposition adjourned at 2:38 p.m.)
